Analysis

What Gartner Gets Right About AI in Product Marketing ‚Äî And the One Thing They're Missing

A conversation with Gartner Fellow David Yockelson on the Defend/Extend/Upend framework ‚Äî and why the real prize isn't the activities, it's what happens between them.

üìÖ February 11, 2026 ‚è±Ô∏è 7 min read ‚úçÔ∏è Christopher O'Hara

I sat down on Tuesday with David Yockelson ‚Äî a Research VP and Gartner Fellow who leads their product marketing practice ‚Äî and asked him to help us figure out how we should be thinking about deploying AI agents across our team ‚Äì and how to contemplate the changes coming to product marketing.

David spent years in the trenches at IBM, Vista Equity Partners, and Meta Group before joining Gartner, so he comes at product marketing research with a practitioner's instinct for what actually works versus what looks good on a slide. And he's been watching the same thing we have: every PMM team in the industry frantically adopting AI tools with no coherent theory of which activities to transform, in what order, and why.

What he walked me through was the most useful prioritization model I've seen for this problem. Three ideas. Let me unpack them.

The Framework Your Team Needs on the Wall

David's categorization looked at every meaningful PMM activity and mapped them into one of three buckets based on what AI does to it. Gartner calls them GenAI Business Case Types, and what makes the framework useful isn't just the categories ‚Äî it's how clearly they map to different competitive ambitions, different return profiles, and wildly different investment levels.

Competitive Ambition: Parity

üõ°Ô∏è Defend

You're augmenting individual productivity to keep up with the pack. Content generation lives here today. AI writes the first draft of a case study or a blog post, a human shapes and sharpens it, and you get a clear productivity win. But the output is fundamentally the same kind of thing you were already producing.

Expected Return: "Return on Employee" ‚Äî improved well-being, better employee NPS
Investment: ~$500 per worker per year (the Copilot license tier)
Competitive Ambition: Differentiation

üìà Extend

Now you're playing for differentiation ‚Äî transforming an existing process or team to gain a competitive advantage. Competitive intelligence is a good example. When you move from manually updating battlecards once a quarter to having AI agents continuously monitoring competitor moves, pricing changes, product announcements, analyst reports ‚Äî you haven't just sped up the old process. You're getting something qualitatively different. The activity looks the same on paper. The results don't.

Expected Return: "Return on Investment" ‚Äî actual financial return
Investment: $250K to $5M (project-level funding)
Competitive Ambition: Disruption

üöÄ Upend

This is where it gets interesting ‚Äî and expensive. Creating new products, new value propositions, new markets. Think cross-functional GTM workflows orchestrated by AI agents, where segmentation feeds persona development feeds hyper-personalized campaign creation feeds dynamic sales outreach, all connected through shared data and automated decisioning. You're not optimizing handoffs between teams. You're eliminating them.

Expected Return: "Return on Future" ‚Äî a strategic bet
Investment: $20M to $250M+ (drug discovery territory, AI-created investment fund territory)

Not Everything Deserves an AI Copilot

The second insight is the one most PMM leaders are getting wrong right now. David mapped core product marketing activities against recommended resource approaches, and the recommendations are not uniform.

This matters, because the instinct in most organizations is to throw AI at everything equally ‚Äî roll out Copilot, give everyone a ChatGPT license, see what happens. That's an adoption strategy. It's not an orchestration strategy.

  • Content generation? Gartner says AI-led. Today. Not human-led with AI assistance ‚Äî AI-led. You should be buying, not building. Humans edit and direct; the machine writes the first draft.
  • ICP and segmentation refinement? Follows a completely different trajectory ‚Äî human-led today, migrating toward hybrid, eventually AI-led. The technology play is ABM platforms and GTM data orchestration that leverage intent signals to discover new cohorts. You can't just hand this to an LLM and walk away. Not yet.
  • Value proposition articulation? Stays human-led to hybrid, with agents on the horizon.
  • Win/loss analysis? Hybrid with a buy recommendation ‚Äî tools that combine human interviewing with proprietary analysis.
  • Buyer persona development? This one surprised me ‚Äî gets a build recommendation, not buy. The custom approach may actually be faster and more fit-for-purpose right now than anything on the market.

The pattern across these activities: each one has its own trajectory and its own build-versus-buy calculus. If your AI strategy is a single horizontal tool rolled out to the whole team, you're solving the wrong problem.

The Real Prize Isn't the Activities ‚Äî It's What Happens Between Them

This is where David's thinking connects directly to something we're going to build toward with the Future of PMM project.

Automating discrete PMM activities is table stakes. The real value comes from connecting those activities through shared data access and AI-driven decisioning to create transformed workflows that span functions.

Marketing to sales. Product marketing to demand gen to customer success. These are complex, cross-functional processes, and they're where agentic AI comes into play ‚Äî not as a tool for individual tasks, but as an orchestration layer for multi-step workflows that no single team owns.

Check out the analysis we've been building using the Pragmatic Institute's 37-activity framework.

Gartner is validating something: the right unit of analysis for AI transformation in PMM is the activity. Not the team, not the tool, not the org chart. You go activity by activity, assess the pain and value at each level, and make deliberate decisions about resources and technology accordingly.

David also made a point that deserves more airtime than it gets: don't repave the cowpath. Don't just automate your current processes if those processes are broken. Focus on the outcomes you want and work backward ‚Äî even if that means fundamentally rethinking how things get done. Automating a bad process with AI gives you a faster bad process, and I suspect most of us have already seen enough of those to last a career.

What We're Going to Do With This

As Dan mentioned, we are running two surveys ‚Äî a Gartner one and this AI Tools assessment I created (please take it if you have not already). We are going to take both sets of results and map them against the Defend / Extend / Upend framework to build a prioritized transformation roadmap.

Activity by activity:

  • Where are we defending today that we could be extending?
  • Where are we over-investing in tools for activities that are still fundamentally human-led?
  • Where's the connective tissue between activities that could unlock cross-functional workflows we haven't built yet?

Let's see what we find out!

Christopher O'Hara is VP of Product Marketing at SAP, where he leads AI and next-generation marketing strategy. He's the author of "Customer Data Platforms" (Wiley) and writes about the future of product marketing at futureofpmm.com.
